restrictionInstructions.dataDistribution: To be made available to all N219 Project by S1000D users.

exportRegistrationStmt.simplePara: Export of this data module to all countries that are the residence of organizations that are users of S1000D is permitted. Storage of this data module is to be at the discretion of the organization.

restrictionInstructions.dataHandling: There are no specific handling instructions for this data module.
restrictionInstructions.dataDestruction: Users may destroy this data module in accordance with their own local procedures.
restrictionInstructions.dataDisclosure: There are no dissemination limitations that apply to this data module.

brCategoryDescription.para: Product definition business rules cover the data module coding strategy related to how the Product is broken down (eg, physical or functional). Included is the definition of the model identification codes to be used in the Product and its subsystems. Supplier subsystems and identifications also need to be considered.

brDecisionPointContent.title: Use of "I" and "O":

brDecisionPointText.para: Decide whether and when to use the alpha characters "I" and "O".

brDecisionPointValue.para: In case of Yes, decide in which specific cases the characters "I" and "O" are allowed to be used in codes (like in model identification codes).
In case of No, consider whether there should be exceptions defined (like the use of the characters of "I" and "O" characters in model identification codes).

brCategory.title: Maintenance philosophy and concepts of operation business rules

brCategoryDescription.para: Maintenance philosophy and concepts of operation business rules cover the types of information that a project or an organization requires. They include for example a list or detailed specification of chosen information sets, an information codes specification which details the information codes, and information names that describe the data module content.

brDecisionPointContent.title: Information sets to be used:

brDecisionPointText.para: Decide which information sets, given in S1000D and/or project specific, to be used.

brDecisionPointValue.para: A list of information sets chosen and defined by the given organization/project.

Data output business rules specify the output formats for S1000D data. These formats can include page-oriented (eg, paper, pdf) formats, IETP formats, multimedia formats and SCORM formats. The decision regarding which portion of the data will be published in what formats must be agreed and written within these business rules.

brDecisionPointContent.title: Possible deliverables:

brDecisionPointText.para:
Decide on the possible deliverables, such as:
S1000D objects (eg, data modules, publication modules, illustration sheets and multimedia objects, data management lists) using file based transfer. Refer to Chap
Information interchange File based transfer Variant Test
.
Page-oriented publications and/or interactive electronic technical publications

brDecisionPointValue.para: A list of deliverable types to be produced by or for the given organization/project. This covers data both in S1000D and external formats.

brCategoryDescription.para: The rules for how data must be exchanged between partners and customers are covered in business rule category 7. This includes for example the use of data dispatch notes and how data management requirement lists as well as CSDB status lists are used. The rules in this category include how the S1000D file based transfer protocol is used, the frequency of data exchanges, if unverified data are exchanged, the rules for data module and graphic issue numbers, and the acceptance and rejection criteria.

brDecisionPointContent.title: Frequency of data exchanges:

brDecisionPointText.para: Decide on the frequency of data exchanges.

brDecisionPointValue.para: There might be a number of different frequencies of data exchange depending on the type of information to be exchanged and on the contractual documents of the organizations and other projects involved.

2 (next higher level of security classification, eg, Restricted)

4 (next higher level of security classification, eg, Secret)
5 (next higher level of security classification, eg, Top secret)

7 (another level of security classification)
8 (another level of security classification)
9 (another level of security classification)
Available for projects

brCategoryDescription.para: The rules for how data must be exchanged between partners and customers are covered in business rule category 7. This includes for example the use of data dispatch notes and how data management requirement lists as well as CSDB status lists are used. The rules in this category include how the S1000D file based transfer protocol is used, the frequency of data exchanges, if unverified data are exchanged, the rules for data module and graphic issue numbers, and the acceptance and rejection criteria.

brDecisionPointContent.title: Define the format of the cross-reference attributes id and internalRefId:

brDecisionPointText.para:
Decide whether the values of the cross-reference attributes id and internalRefId must be prefixed by alpha characters that identify the type of the target element. Example:
Structure: Prefix followed by a hyphen and a four digit number to make it unique within the data module (eg, "par-0001").
Prefixes:
"fig" for figures and alternates
"tab" for tables
"mma" for multimedia and alternates
"sup" for supplies
"seq" for support equipment
"spa" for spares
"par" for levelled paragraphs and alternates
"stp" for steps of procedure, fault isolation, etc, and alternates
"gra" for graphics (multiple sheets)
"mmo" for multimedia objects
"hot" for hotspots (eg, "fig-0001-hot-0002")
"pme" for parameters
"zon" for zones
"wla" for work locations
"mat" for single material or material sets
"msl" for material set lists
"acp for access points
The four digit number has no connection to, for example, the figure or table number which is generated for data module presentation. For example, the value of the attribute id can be "fig-0345" for "Fig 1". Refer to Para 2.1.
Refer to Chap
for the equivalent business rule decision point regarding footnotes. Example: "ftn-0001".

brDecisionPointValue.para: In case of Yes, define identification format requirements.

brCategory.title: Data creation business rules - Illustrations and multimedia

brCategoryDescription.para: Illustration and multimedia creation business rules cover the creation of illustrations and multimedia objects. They are divided into style, detail and data format.

brDecisionPointContent.title: Types of legends:

brDecisionPointText.para:
Decide on the strategy for legends, if used. Legends can appear as part of the illustration or as text using the element <legend>. The advantage of making the legend part of the text is that:
the same illustration can have different legends wherever it appears (eg, in multi-language projects)
the text of the element <legend> can be searched (this might not be the case if the legend is part of the illustration)
items in the illustration can be linked to the legend by the use of hotspots
the legend in the text can save space on the illustration (particularly when the legends are long)

brDecisionPointValue.para: Strategy defnition for legends.

brCategoryDescription.para: Data output business rules specify the output formats for S1000D data. These formats can include page-oriented (eg, paper, pdf) formats, IETP formats, multimedia formats and SCORM formats. The decision regarding which portion of the data will be published in what formats must be agreed and written within these business rules.

Text creation business rules consist of rules and guidelines (including terminology rules such as language and dictionaries, and the order of preference) for maximizing the amount of reuse that can be achieved within technical publications, and between technical publications and supporting training content.

brDecisionPointContent.title: Unit of measure to be used:

brDecisionPointText.para: If using the value and tolerance decomposition, decide at which level of the markup the attribute quantityUnitOfMeasure must be included. Allowable locations are on the parent element <quantityGroup> which applies to all child elements or on the individual child elements <quantityValue> and <quantityTolerance>. A consistent usage of the attribute quantityUnitOfMeasure is required to produce a consistent display or printout to the user.

brDecisionPointValue.para: If the value and tolerance decomposition is used, define at which level of markup the attribute quantityUnitOfMeasure is included.

brCategoryDescription.para: Product definition business rules cover the data module coding strategy related to how the Product is broken down (eg, physical or functional). brCategory.title: Legacy data conversion, management and handling business rules

brCategoryDescription.para: Legacy data conversion, management and handling business rules are quite separate from the other categories outlined above and can be considered (to some extent) as being outside of the scope of S1000D. They cover rules for converting data from say, an ATA iSpec 2200 project, to data modules and will vary from project to project depending on the format of the source data (word processor, paper, Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML)), and how the target data modules must be treated.

brDecisionPointContent.title: Maximum number of subordinate levelled paragraphs in a descriptive data module:

brDecisionPointText.para: Decide on the maximum number of levelled paragraphs allowed in a descriptive data module. Exceeding five levels of depth is strongly discouraged in development of new data. It is recommended that additional levels are only used in a conversion effort where the existing data is authored to this depth (maximum eight levels) and restructuring of data is not feasible.

brCategory.title: Maintenance philosophy and concepts of operation business rules

brCategoryDescription.para: Maintenance philosophy and concepts of operation business rules cover the types of information that a project or an organization requires. They include for example a list or detailed specification of chosen information sets, an information codes specification which details the information codes, and information names that describe the data module content.

Business process business rules cover how technical publications development is coordinated with other disciplines within an organization or within the project level at that organization or the project as a whole. For example, they describe the rules and relationships with LSA, S2000M compliant initial provisioning, engineering/design and training (eg, SCORM conformance).

brDecisionPointContent.title: Developing learning objectives:

brDecisionPointText.para:
Decide whether to develop learning objectives in accordance with task analysis items. Learning objectives ought to be developed in accordance with task analysis items that support system maintenance and operational procedures. Aligning learning objectives with task analysis items in the early content preplanning stages will foster reusable data and content alignment. Refer to Chap
for content preplanning discussions.

The rules for how data must be exchanged between partners and customers are covered in business rule category 7. This includes for example the use of data dispatch notes and how data management requirement lists as well as CSDB status lists are used. The rules in this category include how the S1000D file based transfer protocol is used, the frequency of data exchanges, if unverified data are exchanged, the rules for data module and graphic issue numbers, and the acceptance and rejection criteria.

brCategory.title: Maintenance philosophy and concepts of operation business rules

brCategoryDescription.para: Maintenance philosophy and concepts of operation business rules cover the types of information that a project or an organization requires. They include for example a list or detailed specification of chosen information sets, an information codes specification which details the information codes, and information names that describe the data module content.

brCategory.title: Data integrity and management business rules

brCategoryDescription.para: Data integrity and management business rules enforce the referential integrity within the CSDB. Closely coupled with the data exchange business rules they cover how data is managed by both the creator and the customer.

Data output business rules specify the output formats for S1000D data. These formats can include page-oriented (eg, paper, pdf) formats, IETP formats, multimedia formats and SCORM formats. The decision regarding which portion of the data will be published in what formats must be agreed and written within these business rules.

Business process business rules cover how technical publications development is coordinated with other disciplines within an organization or within the project level at that organization or the project as a whole. For example, they describe the rules and relationships with LSA, S2000M compliant initial provisioning, engineering/design and training (eg, SCORM conformance).

Text creation business rules consist of rules and guidelines (including terminology rules such as language and dictionaries, and the order of preference) for maximizing the amount of reuse that can be achieved within technical publications, and between technical publications and supporting training content.

Security business rules cover all security issues and intellectual property rights. They include security classifications, copyright markings, use or disclosure restrictions, destruction instructions and any other data restrictions.

Data output business rules specify the output formats for S1000D data. These formats can include page-oriented (eg, paper, pdf) formats, IETP formats, multimedia formats and SCORM formats. brCategory.title: Legacy data conversion, management and handling business rules

brCategoryDescription.para: Legacy data conversion, management and handling business rules are quite separate from the other categories outlined above and can be considered (to some extent) as being outside of the scope of S1000D. They cover rules for converting data from say, an ATA iSpec 2200 project, to data modules and will vary from project to project depending on the format of the source data (word processor, paper, Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML)), and how the target data modules must be treated.

brCategory.title: Maintenance philosophy and concepts of operation business rules

brCategoryDescription.para: Maintenance philosophy and concepts of operation business rules cover the types of information that a project or an organization requires. They include for example a list or detailed specification of chosen information sets, an information codes specification which details the information codes, and information names that describe the data module content.

Business process business rules cover how technical publications development is coordinated with other disciplines within an organization or within the project level at that organization or the project as a whole. For example, they describe the rules and relationships with LSA, S2000M compliant initial provisioning, engineering/design and training (eg, SCORM conformance).

Product definition business rules cover the data module coding strategy related to how the Product is broken down (eg, physical or functional). Included is the definition of the model identification codes to be used in the Product and its subsystems. Supplier subsystems and identifications also need to be considered.

brCategory.title: Legacy data conversion, management and handling business rules

brCategoryDescription.para: Legacy data conversion, management and handling business rules are quite separate from the other categories outlined above and can be considered (to some extent) as being outside of the scope of S1000D. They cover rules for converting data from say, an ATA iSpec 2200 project, to data modules and will vary from project to project depending on the format of the source data (word processor, paper, Standard Generalized Markup Language (SGML)), and how the target data modules must be treated.

brCategory.title: Data integrity and management business rules

brCategoryDescription.para: Data integrity and management business rules enforce the referential integrity within the CSDB. Closely coupled with the data exchange business rules they cover how data is managed by both the creator and the customer.
